message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Towards a Mechanization of Fraud Proof Games in Lean
Paper Abstract: Arbitration games from Referee Delegation of Computations are central to layer two optimistic rollup architectures (L2), one of the most prominent mechanisms for scaling blockchains. L2 blockchains operate on the principle that computations are valid unless proven otherwise. Challenging incorrect computations requires users to construct fraud proofs through a dispute resolution process that involves two opposing players. Fraud proofs are objects that establish when proposed computations are invalid, and they are so computationally small and cheap that can be checked by the underlying trusted blockchain. Arbitration games, this challenging process, involve one player posing strategic questions and another player revealing details about computations. Arbitration games start from the posting of Disputable Assertions (DAs), DAs contain partial information about computations including their result. Since there is no trust between players, hashes are posted as compact witnesses of knowledge. One player provides information decomposing hashes while the other decides which "path" to take navigating the computation trace. When a path is exhausted, all the required information to compute the result from the data provided following the path has been revealed and the path can be proven to be faulty or correct. We explore in this paper the formalization of arbitration games in Lean4, introducing the first machine-checkable strategies that honest players can play guaranteeing success. These strategies ensure: on one side, the successful debunking of dishonest computations via the construction of fraud proofs, while in the other, the successful navigation of the challenge process through correct answers. In short, these are the winning strategies that honest players (on both sides) can follow. We explore in this paper formal abstractions to capture disputable assertions, arbitration games on finite binary trees asserting data-availability and membership, game transformations, and then discuss how to work towards a general formal framework for referee delegation of computations.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's information about blockchain:

## What is Blockchain?

A blockchain is a distributed ledger with growing lists of records (blocks) that are securely linked together via cryptographic hashes.(no content)Each block contains a cryptographic hash of the previous block, a timestamp, and transaction data (generally represented as a Merkle tree, where data nodes are represented by leaves).

## Key Characteristics

Since each block contains information about the previous block, they effectively form a chain, with each additional block linking to the ones before it. Consequently, blockchain transactions are resistant to alteration because, once recorded, the data in any given block cannot be changed retroactively without altering all subsequent blocks and obtaining network consensus to accept these changes.(no content)Blockchains are typically managed by a peer-to-peer (P2P) computer network for use as a public distributed ledger, where nodes collectively adhere to a consensus algorithm protocol to add and validate new transaction blocks.

## History

A blockchain was created by a person (or group of people) using the name (or pseudonym) Satoshi Nakamoto in 2008 to serve as the public distributed ledger for bitcoin cryptocurrency transactions. The implementation of the blockchain within bitcoin made it the first digital currency to solve the double-spending problem without the need for a trusted authority or central server.

The search results also include information about specific blockchain applications and companies, such as blockchain games, various blockchain platforms like TRON and Chainlink, and cryptocurrency wallet services.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's information about blockchain:

## What is Blockchain?

A blockchain is a distributed ledger with growing lists of records (blocks) that are securely linked together via cryptographic hashes.(no content)Each block contains a cryptographic hash of the previous block, a timestamp, and transaction data (generally represented as a Merkle tree, where data nodes are represented by leaves).

## Key Characteristics

Since each block contains information about the previous block, they effectively form a chain, with each additional block linking to the ones before it. Consequently, blockchain transactions are resistant to alteration because, once recorded, the data in any given block cannot be changed retroactively without altering all subsequent blocks and obtaining network consensus to accept these changes.(no content)Blockchains are typically managed by a peer-to-peer (P2P) computer network for use as a public distributed ledger, where nodes collectively adhere to a consensus algorithm protocol to add and validate new transaction blocks.

## History

A blockchain was created by a person (or group of people) using the name (or pseudonym) Satoshi Nakamoto in 2008 to serve as the public distributed ledger for bitcoin cryptocurrency transactions. The implementation of the blockchain within bitcoin made it the first digital currency to solve the double-spending problem without the need for a trusted authority or central server.

The search results also include information about specific blockchain applications and companies, such as blockchain games, various blockchain platforms like TRON and Chainlink, and cryptocurrency wallet services.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Formal verification"

Links: [{"title":"Formal verification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_verification"},{"title":"ISP Formal Verification Tool - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISP_Formal_Verification_Tool"},{"title":"Formal methods - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_methods"},{"title":"Verification condition generator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verification_condition_generator"},{"title":"High-level verification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High-level_verification"},{"title":"Verification and validation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verification_and_validation"},{"title":"Compiler correctness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compiler_correctness"},{"title":"Murφ - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mur%CF%86"},{"title":"Joseph Sifakis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._Sifakis"},{"title":"IBM Israel - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IBM_Haifa_Labs"}]

## Formal Verification

Formal verification is the use of software tools to prove properties of a formal specification, or to prove that a formal model of a system implementation satisfies its specification.

### Key Approaches

There are several main techniques used in formal verification:

1. **Model Checking**: A system verifies certain properties by means of an exhaustive search of all possible states that a system could enter during its execution.

2. **Automated Theorem Proving**: A system attempts to produce a formal proof from scratch, given a description of the system, a set of logical axioms, and a set of inference rules.

3. **Abstract Interpretation**: A system verifies an over-approximation of a behavioural property of the program, using a fixpoint computation over a (possibly complete) lattice representing it.

### Applications and Industry Use

Formal verification is used by most or all leading hardware companies, but its use in the software industry is still languishing.(no content)Formal methods are applied in different areas of hardware and software, including routers, Ethernet switches, routing protocols, security applications, and operating system microkernels such as seL4.

### Challenges

Industrial use is limited owing to the computational cost of existing techniques. Additionally, if the program that aids in the verification is itself unproven, there may be reason to doubt the soundness of the produced results.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Merkle tree - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Merkle_tree"},{"title":"Merkle signature scheme - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Merkle_signature_scheme"},{"title":"Talk:Merkle tree - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Merkle_tree"},{"title":"Hash tree - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hash_tree"},{"title":"Hash calendar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hash_calendar"},{"title":"Hash-based cryptography - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hash-based_cryptography"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about Merkle trees:

## Definition

A Merkle tree (also called a hash tree) is a tree in which every "leaf" node is labelled with the cryptographic hash of a data block, and every node that is not a leaf (called a branch, inner node, or inode) is labelled with the cryptographic hash of the labels of its child nodes.

## Key Characteristics

A hash tree allows efficient and secure verification of the contents of a large data structure.(no content)Demonstrating that a leaf node is a part of a given binary hash tree requires computing a number of hashes proportional to the logarithm of the number of leaf nodes in the tree.

## History and Applications

The concept of a hash tree is named after Ralph Merkle, who patented it in 1979.(no content)Hash trees can be used to verify any kind of data stored, handled and transferred in and between computers. They can help ensure that data blocks received from other peers in a peer-to-peer network are received undamaged and unaltered, and even to check that the other peers do not lie and send fake blocks.

## Cryptographic Uses

In hash-based cryptography, the Merkle signature scheme is a digital signature scheme based on Merkle trees (also called hash trees) and one-time signatures such as the Lamport signature scheme.(no content)An advantage of the Merkle signature scheme is that it is believed to be resistant against attacks by quantum computers.

Web search results for query: "Hash function"

Links: [{"title":"Hash function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hash_function"},{"title":"Cryptographic hash function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptographic_hash_function"},{"title":"Hash function security summary - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hash_function_security_summary"},{"title":"Perfect hash function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perfect_hash_function"},{"title":"Non-cryptographic hash function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-cryptographic_hash_function"},{"title":"List of hash functions - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_hash_functions"},{"title":"Skein (hash function) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skein_(hash_function)"},{"title":"Quark (hash function) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quark_(hash_function)"},{"title":"Jenkins hash function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jenkins_hash_function"},{"title":"Security of cryptographic hash functions - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Security_of_cryptographic_hash_functions"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about hash functions:

## What is a Hash Function?

In a hash table, a hash function takes a key as an input, which is associated with a datum or record and used to identify it to the data storage and retrieval application.

## Key Properties

A good hash function satisfies two basic properties: it should be very fast to compute, and it should minimize duplication of output values (collisions).(no content)A hash function may convert variable-length keys into fixed-length values, scramble the bits of the key so that the resulting values are uniformly distributed over the keyspace, and map the key values into ones less than or equal to the size of the table.

## Types of Hash Functions

There are two main categories:

**Non-Cryptographic Hash Functions:** Non-cryptographic hash functions are hash functions intended for applications that do not need the rigorous security requirements of the cryptographic hash functions and therefore can be faster and less resource-intensive.(no content)Typical uses of non-cryptographic hash functions include bloom filters, hash tables, and count sketches.

**Cryptographic Hash Functions:** Most cryptographic hash functions are designed to take a string of any length as input and produce a fixed-length hash value.(no content)Cryptographic hash functions are used in cybersecurity to secure sensitive data such as passwords.

## Applications

Hash functions are used in conjunction with hash tables to store and retrieve data items or data records. The hash function translates the key associated with each datum or record into a hash code, which is used to index the hash table. Additionally, hash functions are an essential ingredient of the Bloom filter, a space-efficient probabilistic data structure that is used to test whether an element is a member of a set.

## What is a Hash Function?

In a hash table, a hash function takes a key as an input, which is associated with a datum or record and used to identify it to the data storage and retrieval application.

## Key Properties

A good hash function satisfies two basic properties: it should be very fast to compute, and it should minimize duplication of output values (collisions).(no content)A hash function may convert variable-length keys into fixed-length values, scramble the bits of the key so that the resulting values are uniformly distributed over the keyspace, and map the key values into ones less than or equal to the size of the table.

## Types of Hash Functions

There are two main categories:

**Non-Cryptographic Hash Functions:** Non-cryptographic hash functions are hash functions intended for applications that do not need the rigorous security requirements of the cryptographic hash functions and therefore can be faster and less resource-intensive.(no content)Typical uses of non-cryptographic hash functions include bloom filters, hash tables, and count sketches.

**Cryptographic Hash Functions:** Most cryptographic hash functions are designed to take a string of any length as input and produce a fixed-length hash value.(no content)Cryptographic hash functions are used in cybersecurity to secure sensitive data such as passwords.

## Applications

Hash functions are used in conjunction with hash tables to store and retrieve data items or data records. The hash function translates the key associated with each datum or record into a hash code, which is used to index the hash table. Additionally, hash functions are an essential ingredient of the Bloom filter, a space-efficient probabilistic data structure that is used to test whether an element is a member of a set.

Links: [{"title":"Lean (proof assistant) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lean_(proof_assistant)"},{"title":"Talk:Lean (proof assistant) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Lean_(proof_assistant)"},{"title":"Proof assistant - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proof_assistant"},{"title":"Category:Proof assistants - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Proof_assistants"},{"title":"Category:Theorem proving software systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Theorem_proving_software_systems"},{"title":"Isabelle (proof assistant) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isabelle_(proof_assistant)"},{"title":"Lean - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lean"},{"title":"Computer-assisted proof - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer-assisted_proof"},{"title":"Automated theorem proving - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_theorem_proving"},{"title":"Mathematical proof - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_proof"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Lean:

## Overview

Lean is a proof assistant and a functional programming language.(no content)It is based on the calculus of constructions with inductive types.(no content)It is an open-source project hosted on GitHub.

## Development and Support

Development is currently supported by the non-profit Lean Focused Research Organization (FRO).(no content)In 2023, the Lean FRO was formed, with the goals of improving the language's scalability and usability, and implementing proof automation.(no content)In 2025, ACM SIGPLAN Programming Languages Software Award was awarded to Gabriel Ebner, Soonho Kong, Leo de Moura and Sebastian Ullrich for Lean, cited for its "significant impact on mathematics, hardware and software verification, and AI".

## Mathematical Libraries

In 2017, a community-maintained project to develop a Lean library mathlib began, with the goal to digitize as much of pure mathematics as possible in one large cohesive library, up to research level mathematics. As of May 2025, mathlib had formalized over 210,000 theorems and 100,000 definitions in Lean.

## Notable Applications

Lean has received attention from mathematicians such as Thomas Hales, Kevin Buzzard, Terence Tao, and Heather Macbeth. Buzzard uses it for the Xena project. One of the Xena Project's goals is to rewrite every theorem and proof in the undergraduate math curriculum of Imperial College London in Lean.(no content)In 2024, Google DeepMind created AlphaProof which proves mathematical statements in Lean at the level of a silver medalist at the International Mathematical Olympiad. This was the first AI system that achieved a medal-worthy performance on a math olympiad's problems.

## Lean 4

In 2021, Lean 4 was released, which was a reimplementation of the Lean theorem prover capable of producing C code which is then compiled, enabling the development of efficient domain-specific automation.

I've completed a web search for "Game theory." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Game theory is the study of mathematical models of strategic interactions.(no content)It has applications in many fields of social science, and is used extensively in economics, logic, systems science and computer science.

## History and Development

Initially, game theory addressed two-person zero-sum games, in which a participant's gains or losses are exactly balanced by the losses and gains of the other participant.(no content)Modern game theory began with the idea of mixed-strategy equilibria in two-person zero-sum games and its proof by John von Neumann. His paper was followed by Theory of Games and Economic Behavior (1944), co-written with Oskar Morgenstern, which considered cooperative games of several players.

## Key Contributions

Nash's most famous contribution to game theory is the concept of the Nash equilibrium, which is a solution concept for non-cooperative games, published in 1951. A Nash equilibrium is a set of strategies, one for each player, such that no player can improve their payoff by unilaterally changing their strategy.

## Scope and Applications

It is now an umbrella term for the science of rational decision making in humans, animals, and computers.(no content)Fifteen game theorists have won the Nobel Prize in economics as of 2020, including most recently Paul Milgrom and Robert B. Wilson.

I've completed a web search for "Game theory." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Game theory is the study of mathematical models of strategic interactions.(no content)It has applications in many fields of social science, and is used extensively in economics, logic, systems science and computer science.

## History and Development

Initially, game theory addressed two-person zero-sum games, in which a participant's gains or losses are exactly balanced by the losses and gains of the other participant.(no content)Modern game theory began with the idea of mixed-strategy equilibria in two-person zero-sum games and its proof by John von Neumann. His paper was followed by Theory of Games and Economic Behavior (1944), co-written with Oskar Morgenstern, which considered cooperative games of several players.

## Key Contributions

Nash's most famous contribution to game theory is the concept of the Nash equilibrium, which is a solution concept for non-cooperative games, published in 1951. A Nash equilibrium is a set of strategies, one for each player, such that no player can improve their payoff by unilaterally changing their strategy.

## Scope and Applications

It is now an umbrella term for the science of rational decision making in humans, animals, and computers.(no content)Fifteen game theorists have won the Nobel Prize in economics as of 2020, including most recently Paul Milgrom and Robert B. Wilson.

Web search results for query: "Binary tree data structure"

Links: [{"title":"Binary tree - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binary_tree"},{"title":"Binary search tree - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binary_search_tree"},{"title":"Search tree - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Search_tree"},{"title":"B-tree - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/B-tree"},{"title":"Heap (data structure) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heap_(data_structure)"},{"title":"Tree (abstract data type) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tree_(abstract_data_type)"},{"title":"M-tree - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/M-tree"},{"title":"Radix tree - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radix_tree"},{"title":"Random binary tree - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Random_binary_tree"},{"title":"Self-balancing binary search tree - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-balancing_binary_search_tree"}]

## Binary Tree Data Structure

I found comprehensive information about binary trees. Here's an overview:

### Definition
A binary tree is a tree data structure in which each node has at most two children, referred to as the left child and the right child.

### Key Characteristics
A tree is a widely used abstract data type that represents a hierarchical tree structure with a set of connected nodes. Each node in the tree can be connected to many children (depending on the type of tree), but must be connected to exactly one parent, except for the root node, which has no parent.

### Structure and Implementation
In a language with records and references, binary trees are typically constructed by having a tree node structure which contains some data and references to its left child and its right child. Sometimes it also contains a reference to its unique parent. If a node has fewer than two children, some of the child pointers may be set to a special null value, or to a special sentinel node.

### Common Applications
Binary trees are used to implement binary search trees and binary heaps, and are used for efficient searching and sorting.(no content)A common implementation of a heap is the binary heap, in which the tree is a complete binary tree.

### Balanced vs. Degenerate Trees
A balanced binary tree is a binary tree structure in which the left and right subtrees of every node differ in height by no more than 1. In contrast, a degenerate (or pathological) tree is where each parent node has only one associated child node. This means that the tree will behave like a linked list data structure.

Based on my search results, I can provide you with information about optimistic rollups in cryptocurrency:

## What are Optimistic Rollups?

Optimistic rollups are one of the different types of Layer 2 (L2) chains, along with zero-knowledge rollups (zk rollups). Layer 2 is one of the approaches that the Ethereum ecosystem has developed in order to scale up and handle more transactions with lower transaction fees, where a Layer 2 chain is a separate blockchain that extends Ethereum (Layer 1) and inherits the security guarantees of Ethereum.

## Performance Benefits

Depending on their individual technical details, some L2 chains are capable of processing thousands of transactions per second, which is a significant improvement over Layer 1 blockchain speeds.

The basic concept behind optimistic rollups is that they bundle multiple transactions together and submit them to the main blockchain, which reduces the computational work needed on the base layer and makes transactions faster and cheaper for users.

I've found comprehensive information about cryptographic hash verification. Here's what the search revealed:

## What is Cryptographic Hash Verification?

Hash-based verification ensures that a file has not been corrupted by comparing the file's hash value to a previously calculated value. If these values match, the file is presumed to be unmodified.

## Key Applications

**File Integrity Verification:**
MD5, SHA-1, or SHA-2 hash digests are sometimes published on websites or forums to allow verification of integrity for downloaded files. This practice establishes a chain of trust as long as the hashes are posted on a trusted site – usually the originating site – authenticated by HTTPS.

**Digital Signatures:**
The message is considered authentic if the signature verification succeeds given the signature and recalculated hash digest over the message. The message integrity property of the cryptographic hash is used to create secure and efficient digital signature schemes.

**Password Authentication:**
To authenticate a user, the password presented by the user is hashed and compared with the stored hash.

## Security Considerations

Cryptographic hash functions are employed for file verification purposes. As long as the hash sums cannot be tampered with — for example, if they are communicated over a secure channel — the files can be presumed to be intact.(no content)Best practice recommendations as of 2012 is to use SHA-2 or SHA-3 to generate new file integrity digests.

Links: [{"title":"Proof assistant - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proof_assistant"},{"title":"Isabelle (proof assistant) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isabelle_(proof_assistant)"},{"title":"Automated theorem proving - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_theorem_proving"},{"title":"Lean (proof assistant) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lean_(proof_assistant)"},{"title":"Rocq - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coq_(software)"},{"title":"Matita - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matita"},{"title":"Formal verification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_verification"},{"title":"HOL (proof assistant) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HOL_(proof_assistant)"},{"title":"Formal methods - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_methods"},{"title":"Compiler correctness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compiler_correctness"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about proof assistants and formal methods:

## Proof Assistants

A proof assistant or interactive theorem prover is a software tool to assist with the development of formal proofs by human–machine collaboration.(no content)This involves an interactive proof editor or other interface with which a human can guide the search for proofs, the details of which are stored in, and some steps provided by, a computer.

### Major Proof Assistants

As of September 2025, six systems have formalized proofs of more than 70% of well-known theorems: Isabelle, HOL Light, Lean, Rocq, Metamath and Mizar.

Key systems include:
- **Isabelle**: Isabelle is available in a flexible system framework allowing logically safe extensions and can be seen as an integrated development environment (IDE) for formal methods.
- **Lean**: Lean is a proof assistant and functional programming language based on the calculus of constructions with inductive types.
- **Rocq** (formerly Coq): The Rocq Prover is an interactive theorem prover first released in 1989 that allows expression of mathematical assertions and mechanical checking of proofs.

## Formal Methods

Formal methods are mathematically rigorous techniques for the specification, development, analysis, and verification of software and hardware systems.(no content)The use of formal methods is motivated by the expectation that mathematical analysis can contribute to reliability and robustness, and they employ fundamentals including logic calculi, formal languages, automata theory, program semantics, and type systems.

### Applications

Prominent examples of verified software systems include the CompCert verified C compiler and the seL4 high-assurance operating system kernel.

Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Perfect! I have successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Towards a Mechanization of Fraud Proof Games in Lean". Here's what was accomplished:

## Summary

**Paper Classification:** `contribution` - This paper proposes new formal abstractions and machine-checkable winning strategies for arbitration games in Lean4.

**Triples Identified (10 total):**

1. **Blockchain** (concept, uses) - The underlying trusted layer that arbitration games scale
2. **Lean (proof assistant)** (tool, uses) - The formal verification tool for mechanizing the games
3. **Hash function** (concept, uses) - Compact witnesses of knowledge in arbitration games
4. **Merkle tree** (concept, uses) - Hierarchical structure for data availability assertions
5. **Formal verification** (method, uses) - Core methodology for machine-checking strategies
6. **Rollup** (concept, uses) - Layer two blockchain scaling architecture
7. **Binary tree** (concept, uses) - Underlying structure for arbitration games
8. **Game theory** (concept, uses) - Framework for strategic interactions
9. **Proof assistant** (tool, uses) - Enables interactive theorem proving
10. **Arbitration game** (concept, proposes) - **New contribution:** First formal abstractions and machine-checkable strategies

**Validation Results:** ✅ All checks passed
- Proper paper type classification
- All 10 triples with valid Wikipedia URLs
- Correct entity types and relations
- Meets requirements: At least 1 "uses" relation and at least 1 "proposes" relation for contribution papers

Sources:
- [Blockchain - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blockchain)
- [Lean (proof assistant) - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lean_(proof_assistant))
- [Hash function - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hash_function)
- [Merkle tree - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Merkle_tree)
- [Formal verification - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_verification)
- [Rollup - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rollup)
- [Binary tree - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binary_tree)
- [Game theory - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_theory)
- [Proof assistant - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proof_assistant)
- [Arbitration - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arbitration)
